results.title: Peach's Australia : Murray Riverboats
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Commission and Lloyd Capps
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Peach’s Australia”.
The Murray River has many problems, including pollution, the dwindling of its native fish, and the introduction of the European Carp, but the biggest problem has been in the threatened loss of its history. To Bill Peach, “the riverboats represent the most colourful and romantic part of that history, and the skeletons of riverboats are symbols of our failure to love and care for our greatest river. Written and presented by Bill Peach.

results.title: Peach's Australia : Mount Buffalo
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Commission and Lloyd Capps
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Peach’s Australia”.
It is the position of Mt Buffalo, standing apart from the Victorian Alps, and its extraordinary shape, that have led it to being called Australia’s grandest, wildest, most novel and most romantic mountain.

results.title: Peach's Australia : Hahndorf
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Commission, Alan Bateman and Bill Steller
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Peach’s Australia”.
Traces the history of the town of Hahndorf, South Australia, beginning with the German settlers who arrived at Port Misery (Port Adelaide) in 1838. Outlines their reasons for leaving Germany, the establishment of Klemzig, the movement of some Germans into the Adelaide Hills and the difficulties they encountered. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Peach's Australia : Chinatown: Dixon Street
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Commission and Christopher McCullough
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Peach’s Australia”.
Anti-Chinese riots on the goldfields caused many Chinese to shift to the cities of Sydney and Melbourne. Chinatowns sprung up and became the centres of their business and social life, cultural and racial ghettos, where the people lived and worked together for mutual help and protection. The film looks at Sydney’s Dixon Street where, over half a century ago, two-thirds of Sydney’s Chinese population lived.

results.title: Peace is more than a dream....
results.creator_credit: IKOR, CVK Television and Trudy Van Keulne
results.brief_description: Through the children themselves and their drawings, this film tells the story of 250,000 Palestinian refugee children working for peace in their homeland.

results.title: Peace in no man's land
results.brief_description: On the Western Front on Christmas Day 1915, British and German soldiers ceased fire and fraternized in the “no man’s land” between the trenches. Actual testimony letters are combined with photographs to create the atmosphere of comradeship of line soldiers who believed they were just doing their duty.

results.title: Peace in action
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Ministry of Education and Jeff Spencer
results.brief_description: Peace is everyone’s responsibility. The peace program views peace issues being developed and taught in schools. Examples from primary and postprimary schools include art, student initiatives, plays, student councils and community interest. Professor Charlesworth raises issues for further discussion in schools

results.title: Peace hotel
results.creator_credit: Cassia Hill Productions, John Woo and Ka-Fai Wai
results.brief_description: Chow Yun-Fat is ‘The Killer’, a man famous for having slaughtered a large number of bandits at an inn ten years before. Following the massacre, he ran off to the North-west frontier and established the ‘peace hotel’, a place where anyone can come to seek refuge. The strange order of the hotel is disturbed by the arrival of Shau Siu Man (Cecilia Yip), who is being pursued by a gang. A swindler and a compulsive liar, Shau Siu Man is unable to produce an explanation regarding her situation, but nevertheless begs The Killer to extend hospitality and protection. As the gang gathers around the hotel, the leader delivers an ultimatum to The Killer to surrender the woman or they will storm the hotel. Haunted by remorse over his violent past and lost love, The Killer must decide between risking an all-out war with a determined gang or break his promise of a safe haven to all. ‘Peace Hotel’ is an action-packed take on the (spaghetti) western genre, complete with dust coats and bar brawls, alternating sword fighting sequences with machine gun attacks. Although the plot is at time obscure, elements common to John Woo’s and Chow Yun-Fat’s previous collaborations emerge, such as honour among thieves and the search for redemption. ‘Peace Hotel’ was the last Hong-Kong movie starring Chow Yun-Fat before he embarked on his American career with ‘The Replacement Killers’. It is with ‘All about Ah-long’ the second film for which he is credited as a writer. In Cantonese with English subtitles.
